Award.AwardTitle: Sensor-Based Damage Detection and Quantification in Bridges Under Traffic and Environmental Effects

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: This project will develop a robust approach for damage identification (detection and quantification) of bridges exposed to environmental temperature and solar radiation variations and traffic loads. The approach will utilize the modal properties extracted from vibration response data with appropriate adjustments for thermal effects for damage identification. The traffic induced vibration data along with measurements on the moving loads will be used for the extraction of the modal parameters. For the validation of the proposed modal estimation approach, the field data collected on two concrete bridges in Hong Kong will be utilized. For damage identification, the methods based on the improved estimation of the curvature flexibility will be developed. A comprehensive study will be conducted to evaluate the effect of thermal conduction on the modal parameters to propose simple methods utilizing only the yearly and diurnal temperature trends and spot measurements of the temperature at the time of data recording to calculate the temperature affected modal parameters. For damage quantification, the flexibility characteristics of damaged structure will be compared with those of the undamaged baseline structure adjusted to reflect the effect of the temperature environment at the time of the data measurements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of the project research was on damage detection and quantification in bridges under traffic and environmental effects. The research examined the effects of environmental temperature and solar radiation on the dynamic characteristics of bridge structures. In this study, we used modal frequencies as a damage feature representing the structural state. An approach was formulated to predict the thermal effects without carrying out a detailed thermo-mechanical analysis of a bridge. Finite element (FE) simulation was used to generate a range of damage scenarios utilizing the most influential environmental factors such as ambient temperature, solar irradiance and convective effect of the wind from an actual geographical site. The simulation was conducted with 9-year long temperature data collected on the site in the real world environment, providing a rich dataset for development of damage detection algorithm.

It was demonstrated that the previously proposed linear models correlating temperature and modal frequency did not apply to all types of bridges. As a first step towards damage detection, we proposed enhancements to such techniques to increase performance when applied to wider arrays of bridges. But these techniques still required the user to collect a large set of temperature and modal frequency data equally spaced in time over the entire spectrum of environmental conditions. We developed an approach which utilized the correlation within the modal frequencies of the structure. The primary hypothesis is that temperature induced effects cause proportional changes in modal frequencies, while structural damage disrupts the correlation. There are multiple benefits of such a method; firstly, there is no need to record any temperature on the bridge, and secondly, the correlation within modal frequencies is instantaneous and does not require uniformly sampled modal frequency data for real structures. We deployed an advanced statistical algorithm to automatically identify the nonlinear correlation relationship within modal frequencies which used a considerably small and randomly collected dataset. This correlation, when identified under healthy conditions of the structure, represented its healthy state. Any deviation from this healthy state is statistically tested and can be classified as structural damage.

The research study led to the publication of several technical papers which have been published in widely circulated technical journals as well as presented in several national and international conferences for the wider dissemination of the research results.
